item.content:
Today I had a lot of fun building a new site for aubreypwd.com using Hugo and Github Pages.

I haven’t had a lot of time to work on a website, let alone write content for one. In fact, I used to have a pretty nice site, but I never kept up with it, and eventually just redirected it to Twitter. I also tried out write.as to try and publish content, but I found I didn’t really use it a lot.

The kind of site I’ve always wanted is just a simple one: a bit about who I am with links to all the things you can use to find out more about me. Content is sort of a mehâ€”I’d rather be coding :)â€”and I usually blog over @WebDevStudios anyways.

Really, this isn’t even a blog, the only reason I enabled posts is so I could post updates every once in a while… and maybe content… but don’t hold your breath, I mostly post on Twitter.

Hugo?

I’ve always wanted a dead-simple site, I also want a site that is totally under version control (content and all). WordPress doesn’t do that, Hugo does. Plus, it was fun to learn and use something new, and was much easier than (but similar enought to) Jekyll to setup. I would hightly recommend it!

This site is going to be much easier to maintain and deploy than a WordPress one. Also, I could write in Markdown natively, which felt warm-and-fuzzy.

item.content:
This article was moved from thebadstoic.com, which may no longer be active.

Traditionally, the words for the four primary virtues of Stoicism are:

  • Wisdom
  • Justice
  • Courage
  • Temperance

If youâ€™re about to do a thing, you ask yourself:

  • Am I beingÂ Wise?
  • Am I beingÂ Just?
  • Am I beingÂ Courageous?
  • Am I beingÂ Temperate?

But, none of theseÂ wordsÂ have ever reallyÂ meantÂ much for me.Â They donâ€™t reach out to me and explain themselves very well. Theyâ€™re very academic sounding, lofty, and words that donâ€™t guide me towards my next action. Sometimes they leave me asking,Â what do I even do?

So, Iâ€™ve come up with my ownÂ wordsÂ for these virtues:

Wisdom â†’ Truth

What does WisdomÂ reallyÂ mean? â€”Â I thinkÂ it means looking at the world clearly and truthfully. Itâ€™s all about the correct knowledge of whatâ€™s in front of you:

  • What isÂ reallyÂ happening right now?
  • Am I truly in danger of being fired? Is this just my mind racing away from me?
  • What is this personâ€™s story, why are theyÂ reallyÂ acting this way?
  • Why is this bothering me? Is it really that bothersome? IsÂ itÂ actually bothering me, or is it just my attitude towards this thing?

Too often we look at a given situation and judge it almostÂ immediatelyÂ for face value. Marcus (and Epictetus) tell us to not toÂ trust first appearances, especially within our own mind. I think this is at the heart ofÂ Wisdom.Â Itâ€™s the ability to dissect and analyze any given perception or thing for its truth, absent (mostly) of our own judgements and opinions â€”Â seeing things for what they truly are.

Marcus asks us, all the time in theÂ Meditations, to wipe our opinions clean and change themÂ right on the spot! But, it would be wrong to think that Marcus is asking us to just have some change of heart out of no-where. To change our opinions, we needÂ knowledgeÂ and that knowledge needs to be based onÂ truthÂ and examination.

  • Why am I so upset about the dog digging a hole in the yard, is it really that hard to fix? Is the dogÂ tryingÂ to hurt my feelings? Iâ€™m acting as if he is!
  • Is the universe really out to get me? IÂ justÂ got a flat tire because of a nail, and it looks like it fell off a truck on the highway, the guy must have been in a rush for some reason â€” maybe to get to his next job he dearly needs.

Itâ€™s theÂ pauseÂ you take to look at something for what itÂ reallyÂ is, not what youÂ think it is.Â Or, the gall to admit you donâ€™t know enough. With experience this becomes easier,Â obviously, but nothing stops us from pausing and acting when we feel we have the truth of the matter,Â or admitting that we donâ€™t have all the information to act.

Justice â†’ Service

Justice, if youâ€™re like me, comes off veryÂ noble (rightfully so)Â andÂ legislative,Â and more concerned aboutÂ weighingÂ what is right and wrong instead of what actuallyÂ isÂ right and wrong. In the books of the Stoics, Justice comes off more personal and neighborly to me. I use a version of theÂ Golden RuleÂ as a reminder:

Serve others the way you would serve yourself

Itâ€™s aÂ reflectiveÂ virtue.Â It comes with a built-in manual: if you want somethingÂ forÂ yourself, ensureÂ othersÂ get it as well!

  • You want â€œme-time?â€ Give others â€œme-timeâ€!
  • If you want to be understood, try and understand others.
  • If you hate doing the dishes, donâ€™t expect others to enjoy doing the dishes.
  • If you want to be wealthy, help others be wealthy!

The word serveÂ is important, because itâ€™s not enough to just to â€œtreatÂ others the way you would want to be treatedâ€ (which implies that you only do this when you come into contact with them), butÂ servingÂ someone with justice is aÂ dutyÂ and asks of you toÂ go outÂ and help others gain the very thingsÂ youÂ want out of life.

Courage â†’ Fearlessness

Recently I did an entire reading of the entireÂ Meditations, and noted each time a particular theme came up.Â FearlessnessÂ came up often,Â like a lot! It came up in a lot of different ways:

  • Not caring what other people think of you
  • Not caring if people blame you for things
  • Tackling challenging tasks (not fearing them)
  • Not fearing the future
  • Not even caring whether you are going to die!

At one point I think Epictetus asks us, basically, to â€œfear nothing,â€ since all un-folding of life isÂ intendedÂ andÂ natural!Â Since life is going to unfold how it unfolds (either by God or just being the way it is), itâ€™sÂ bestÂ to not go out whining and complaining, butÂ fearlessly!

I have a mental exercise that helps me ascertain how toÂ fearlesslyÂ approach a situation:

Temperance â†’ Detachment

Temperance, when you first hear it â€” it comes off as being cool-headed and patient. These are all good virtues, butÂ howÂ you do that is very hard to discern. In all my studying, Iâ€™ve found that the only way to beÂ temperateÂ is toÂ detach from things.

Hereâ€™s an example (from Epictetus) that I love to exemplify this virtue (paraphrased):

Life is a banquet. When a platter of delicious food is handed to you, sample it. If youâ€™re waiting for the platter to come to you, do not seek it out, wait for it to come to you. If it never comes, pay no matter to it.

I feel like the central theme here isÂ detachment. â€œSample itâ€ he says, which seems to imply actuallyÂ enjoying thingsÂ (which is awesome right), but done so in moderated way (e.g.Â sample). Further reading will show that itâ€™sÂ reallyÂ the concern ofÂ attachmentÂ to pleasant things that is being disciplined. The gist ofÂ most of the StoicsÂ is that if you continually enjoy nice things, you will develop habits and familiarity with them, which couldÂ attachÂ you to said external thing â€” say if it goes away.

Furthermore, he goes on to instruct that if the platter floats about the room, to notÂ wantÂ after it or seek it out. And, even more so, if it never makes its way over to you, or you were accidentallyÂ skipped, to pay no matter to it.

Detach from things: expectations, outcomes, wealth, behaviors, etc. It doesnâ€™t mean donâ€™t expect anything, or not enjoy a wealth. ButÂ sampleÂ them, moderately and appropriately, and pay no matter if they donâ€™t even come to you.

Donâ€™t be attached toÂ it,Â whateverÂ itÂ is.

Find truth, serve others, be fearless, and detach!
